worksheet.title: Elementary matrices

statement.p:
Consider the matrices
E \amp = \begin{bmatrix} 1 \amp 0 \amp 0\\2 \amp 1 \amp 0\\0 \amp 0 \amp 1\end{bmatrix}, \amp A \amp = \left[\begin{array}{rrrr} 1 \amp 1 \amp -1 \amp 0 \\ -2 \amp 0 \amp 1 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp -1 \amp 0 \amp 3 \end{array}\right].
Compute EA. What is happening to A when it is multiplied by E?
Think row operations.
Do you think the same thing will happen when computing E times some other matrix?
We know that EI = E. But then consider EI in terms of the first two parts of this activity. So in terms of row operations, what is the relationship between E and I?
Create a 3\times 3 matrix E' so that for every 3\times n matrix A, the result of E' A is the same as applying the row operation multiply row 3 by -4.

hint.p: What was the pattern you identified in Part of ?

statement.p: Create a 3\times 3 matrix E'' so that for every 3 \times n matrix A, the result of E'' A is the same as applying the row operation swap rows 1 and 2.

hint.p: What was the pattern you identified in Part of ?

worksheet.p: Matrices E,E',E'' from the activities so far are called elementary matriceselementarymatrix. As the preceding activities demonstrate, every elementary row operation has a corresponding elementary matrix.

statement.p:
Consider
B = \left[\begin{array}{rrr} 1 \amp 0 \amp -3 \\ 0 \amp 0 \amp 2 \\ 0 \amp 1 \amp 0 \end{array}\right] .
Determine elementary matrices E_1,E_2,E_3 so that E_3 E_2 E_1 B is the identity matrix.
Use the connection between elementary matrices and row operations that we have discovered in this activity set. Consider carefully the order in which the elementary matrices should be multiplied onto B.
The matrix B happens to be invertible. Manipulate the formula E_3 E_2 E_1 B = I algebraically to obtain a formula for \inv{B} involving your elementary matrices and I. (The I factor is not strictly necessary, but is important for the next step.)
Using your formula from part (b) as inspiration, come up with a procedure to use only row reduction (and not elementary matrices) to compute the inverse of a square matrix.
Where did your elementary matrices E_1,E_2,E_3 come from? And what are they now doing to the identity matrix, and in what order?

Consider the general 2\times 2 matrix A = \left[\begin{smallmatrix}a \amp b\\c \amp d\end{smallmatrix}\right].
Assume that a\neq 0. Use the method you developed in
to determine the inverse of A.
Did you need to assume anything about ad-bc for this to work? Why?
